subject: tunnel-new: Replace pa_mainloop with pa_rtpoll
commitMessage:
tunnel-new: Replace pa_mainloop with pa_rtpoll

This fixes crashes when trying to use module-rtp-recv or
module-combine-sink together with module-tunnel-sink-new.
module-rtp-recv and module-combine-sink assume that all IO threads use
pa_rtpoll.

Change-Id: I67b3e22b4973d0397e11466a2cf8066e10697b55
BugLink: https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=73429

subject: rtpoll: Implement pa_mainloop_api support
commitMessage:
rtpoll: Implement pa_mainloop_api support

The new tunnel sink and source use libpulse to talk to the remote
server, and libpulse requires a pa_mainloop_api implementation for
interacting with the event loop. The tunnel sink and source have so
far been using pa_mainloop, but there are some modules that assume
that all sinks and sources use pa_rtpoll in their IO threads, and
trying to use those modules together with the pa_mainloop based
tunnel sinks and sources will result in crashes (see [1]).

I will switch the event loop implementation in the tunnel modules
to pa_rtpoll, but that requires a pa_mainloop_api implementation in
pa_rtpoll first - that's implemented here.

pa_rtpoll_run() is changed so that it processes all defer events
first, and then all expired time events. The rest of pa_rtpoll_run()
works as before, except the poll timeout calculation now has to also
take the time events into account. IO events use the existing
pa_rtpoll_item interface.

The time events are handled separately from the old timer
functionality, which is somewhat ugly. It might be a good idea to
remove the old timer functionality and only use the time events.
I didn't attempt to do that at this time, because I feared that
adapting the pa_rtpoll users to the new system would be difficult.

[1] https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=73429

Change-Id: I4f9a92efbdbb868547ee3422538936f8de5d971e

subject: tunnel-sink-new: Fix stale audio on resume
commitMessage:
tunnel-sink-new: Fix stale audio on resume

I noticed that when resuming the tunnel sink, there was a small amount
of previously played audio before the new audio started to play.
Normally that probably wouldn't be noticeable, because there would be
a few seconds of silence played before suspending the sink due to
inactivity, so the unwanted old audio would be just silence, but in my
configuration sinks are suspended immediately when there's nothing
playing to them, so the glitch becomes audible.

Change-Id: I8344d3fbef9d687848e102f09f7367d8613863f5

subject: tunnel-new: remove uncorking in thread_func. Now handled by state change callback.
commitMessage:
tunnel-new: remove uncorking in thread_func. Now handled by state change callback.

tunnel-new handled a corked stream conditional in the thread_func to be
sure the stream isn't corked. Un/Corking is now handled in the
state change callback.

Change-Id: I0474a4cec525293ce61cc0c120bf903014a7c05e
Signed-off-by: Alexander Couzens <lynxis@fe80.eu>

subject: tunnel-new: add un/corking to the state change callback
commitMessage:
tunnel-new: add un/corking to the state change callback

The stream is now corked when the sink or source becomes suspended and
uncorked when it's back idle/ready.

Change-Id: I8eb4c127e68abbb21009161466a73cbb97c4f2e5
Signed-off-by: Alexander Couzens <lynxis@fe80.eu>

subject: module-expose-environment: expose client environment variables.
commitMessage:
module-expose-environment: expose client environment variables.

subject: pulsecore: added reliable PID tracking for (local) clients.
commitMessage:
pulsecore: added reliable PID tracking for (local) clients.

Automatically retrieve and store client credentials if those
are available and enabled. Credentials will be made available
for clients that connect using a socket/protocol family that
is capable of passing credentials (UNIX domain sockets in
practice).

These credentials (PID, user id, and primary group id) can be
used for a number of things, for instance to apply some policy
to clients or object created/owned by clients based on the
user id or group id. Our subsequent patches will use the PID
for implementing a mechanism to make a configurable selection
of whitelisted environment variables available on a per client
basis. A policy enforcement module will then take these into
account when making automatic routing and other decisions.

Note that these credentials have already been queried and
available at the lower communication layers (I/O channels and
pstream). This patch merely propagates them all the way up to
the client.

Currently credentials will not be be available until the first
protocol message is received. If it turns out that credentials
are needed immediately after connection establishment, it is
easy to extend pstream to explictly query the credentials over
its I/O channel instead of waiting for the first packet.

Change-Id: I8ea306761e0b901a1bdf3ec9203920458162d670
Signed-off-by: Krisztian Litkey <kli@iki.fi>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Just a small bit of polishing needed.

Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Looks otherwise good to me, but there was one trivial indenting issue.

subject: pulsecore: added pa_client_getenv.
commitMessage:
pulsecore: added pa_client_getenv.

Added pa_client_getenv, the core function to retrieve
environment variables from clients' environment. The
actual code to retrieve those variables is not in core.
If the functionality is needed a module can be loaded
to provide an implementation.

The default module-expose-environment provides one such
implementation. If it is available but not loaded, it
will be demand-loaded when the first call is made to
pa_client_getenv.

If no such module is available and none of the loaded
modules provides an implementation, it will not be
possible to retrieve client environment variables.

Alternative implementations with more restrictions or
with a different logic are easily possible by loading
a different module that hooks itself up to the same
minimalistic core infra.

Change-Id: I60e784268e8bcbde5d2f9a3f6aefd48b2254badb
Signed-off-by: Krisztian Litkey <kli@iki.fi>
